awd_titl_txt: REU Site: HWS-REU: Discovering Mathematics in New York State
awd_abstract_narration:
Each summer, the Research Experience for Undergraduates program at Hobart and William Smith Colleges (HWS) will provide ten undergraduates a hands-on introduction to mathematics research.  The program will be open to students from across the nation, with a particular focus on recruiting a diverse pool of students from public colleges and universities in New York State. Over the course of the nine-week program, participants will gain independence as researchers and develop the skills to present their results to the broader scientific community and the public. Small research teams of students will be formed to pursue research on topics from a wide variety of mathematical fields under the guidance of HWS faculty members expert in these areas. Additionally, a colloquium series and visits to nearby graduate programs will help participants make informed decisions about pursuing a career as a mathematician. The faculty-student relationships built throughout the program will be extended at least two years beyond the REU through formal check-ins by faculty to assist students in career development.
 
Research projects will explore topics in graph theory, algebra or mathematical biology. In graph theory, topics will include the classification of certain subclasses of well-covered graphs and tree labeling problems related to the graceful tree labeling conjecture. In algebra, monomial ideals will be explored through their connection to combinatorial structures such as graphs and their subgraphs. In mathematical biology, participants may work to develop novel algorithms for reconstructing phylogenetic trees from genetic data, use differential equation models to explore the dynamic interaction of viral infections and the immune responses that combat them, or develop and analyze computational models of networks of neural connections within the brain.

por.por_cntn:
Over three summers a total of 30 students participated in a nine-week mentored research experience at Hobart and William Smith Colleges.  Over 86% of the program participants had at least one identity which historically has been marginalized in the mathematics community and two-thirds of the participants were from institutions with limited research access.  The program focused on providing high-quality, faculty-mentored research support to engage participants in mathematics research and develop them as STEM professionals.

Participants engaged in research in both pure and applied mathematics. Some explored connections between graph theory and abstract algebra.  Others created new theorems in graph labeling, and domination in graphs as well as constructed and analyzed matching games on graphs.  These projects helped shape a better understanding of the interconnected nature of mathematical structures.  Applied mathematicians worked to model the effects of Covid-19, and the immune response to Chronic Hepatitis B.  Others developed strategies for distinguishing different species and providing a mathematical framework for understanding hybridization in the course of evolution.  Another group focused on modeling how information is transferred in the brain.  By having pure and applied mathematicians together, students were able to see how the tools and structures developed in pure mathematics provide the necessary framework for applications of mathematics to society and saw that pure and applied mathematics exist on a continuum and a binary distinction. As a result of their collaborative efforts, all 30 participants presented their findings at national meetings, with nearly half receiving awards for their work.  Several groups have submitted their work for publication with others continuing to work with their faculty mentors to finalize their projects.

The broader impact of this program however is in its contribution to the development of a robust and diverse future generation of scientists and mathematicians.  Of the 30 participants, 21 are already enrolled in graduate programs in mathematics, including Doctoral programs at institutions such as Notre Dame, Dartmouth, and the University of Minnesota. Seven of the students have already begun their STEM careers as biostatisticians, operations research analysts, data analysts, cost analysts, high school mathematics teachers, and a biotechnician who worked to extract RNA from the coronavirus during the pandemic.

Discovering Mathematics in New York State provided a human-centered approach to nurturing the inherent strengths of the program participants.  This model of inclusive mentorship is imperative in growing the US STEM workforce.
